item.description: Introduction # Insight into the clonal composition of a cells during key events – such as development, infection, tumor progression, or treatment response – is critical to understanding the nature of the interaction between the population of cells and the selective forces shaping it. While advances in genomics and transcriptomics and the advent of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) have vastly increased the resolution at which we can understand cellular processes, they lack the ability to directly assign clonal relationships.

Materials # Equipment Electroporator Mammalian cell incubator Bacterial cell incubator with shaking Thermocycler Gel electrophoresis box Bioanalyzer Illumina sequencer Flow cytometer with filters for BFP (Ex: 380/20, Em: 460/40) Disposables Sterile filtered pipette tips 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes (sterile) 1.8 mL Screw top cryovials (sterile) 20 mL Luer-tapered syringe (sterile) 0.45 $\mu$m polyethersulfone (PES) syringe filter 30,000 molecular weight cutoff (MWCO) PES concentrator capable of processing 20 mL Biologics

Methods # sgRNA Barcode Library Plasmid Pool Assembly # Perform an extension reaction to generate double-stranded insert gRNA barcode DNA. Mix 10 $\mu$L NEB 5X Q5 Reaction Buffer, 1 $\mu$L of 10 mM dNTPs, 2 $\mu$L 100$\mu$M CROPseq-PrimeF-BgL-BsmBI, 1 $\mu$L 100$\mu$M CROPseq-RevExt-BgL-BsmBI , and 0.5 $\mu$L to create a 50 $\mu$L reaction.1 See 10X-3.1.1 for 10X vector variation. Run the extension reaction on a thermocycler using the following settings: (1) 98 °C for 2 min, (2) 65 °C for 30 sec, (3) 72 °C for 10 sec, (4) Repeat steps 2-3 for 10 cycles, (5) 72 °C for 1 min, (6) 4 °C hold
